Award.AwardTitle: CPS: TTP Option: Synergy: A Verifiable Framework for Cyber- Physical Attacks and Countermeasures in a Resilient Electric Power Grid

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The electric power grid, a cyber-physical system (CPS), faces an alarmingly high risk of catastrophic damage from cyber-attacks. However, modeling cyber-attacks, evaluating consequences, and developing appropriate countermeasures require a detailed, realistic, and tractable model of electric power CPS operations. The primary barrier is the lack of access to models for the complex legacy proprietary systems upon which the electric power grid has relied for decades. This project aims to overcome these challenges with the development of an attack-verifying (verifiable) software framework that will capture the electric power system operations in adequate detail. Cyber threats will be verified using this framework through a combination of sound theoretical methods and an open-source commercial simulation engine accessible via a unique transition to practice (TTP) option.

This research focuses on four fundamental and related thrusts: (i) identifying classes of cyber-attacks with quantifiable physical consequences and developing detection-based countermeasures; (ii) identifying communication attacks on distributed grid operations and developing information-sharing countermeasures; (iii) developing a verifiable software framework that models the spatio-temporal operations of the electric grid in tandem with thrusts (i) and (ii) to verify attack models, evaluate countermeasures, and develop new resiliency protocols; and (iv) a TTP option, in collaboration with industry-leading experts from IncSys and PowerData, to develop commercial grade open source power simulation software packages to integrate and test the attacks and countermeasures of Thrusts (i) through (iii) as well as develop workforce training curriculum for North American Electric Reliability Council (NERC) certification. This research also includes engagement with K-12 students via the Arizona Science Laboratory program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes: CPS: Verifiable Framework

 

The electric power grid, one of the most complex engineered systems of the 20th century,  requires continuous monitoring and situational awareness for reliable operations. This monitoring is done at multiple timescales and a key part of such telemetry data is the so-called SCADA (supervisory control and data acquisition) system. SCADA data is an integral part of energy management systems (EMSs) at the bulk transmission level and is crucial to enable the real-time decision-making task of energy management via topology and state estimation, real-time contingency analysis, and security constrained economic dispatch. SCADA and EMS are often referred to as the cyber layer of the electric grid.

 

Yet, as is the case for all cyber infrastructure involving sophisticated sensing, control, and communications systems, the electric grid cyber infrastructure is also vulnerable to cyberattacks. In particular, false data injection attacks (FDIAs) that change data in a manner that makes it impossible to immediately sieve such data as noise, are particularly harmful. This project focuses on understanding the effect of sophisticated FDIAs on grid operations, in particular on real-time EMS decisions including topology, load, and state estimation as well as security constrained economic dispatch. Our work included: (i) identifying sophisticated yet feasible cyberattacks that spoof EMS via FDI into making control and actuation decisions based on false estimated loads; (ii) showing in simulation that such attacks can cause line overflows on targeted lines that are unobservable to the operator in the control room; (iii) demonstrating that historical data is needed to design machine learning countermeasures capable of detecting anomalies in load patterns created by FDIA attacks; and finally, (iv) developing a software platform to test and detect attacks.

 

The proof of concept software platform developed by this project involved close collaborations with IncSys and Powerdata, two leading industry experts on power systems simulations and operator training, via a Transition to Practice (TTP) component. This allowed for rigorous testing of both attack and defense models and algorithms on synthetic power systems of varying sizes and complexity ranging from simple IEEE bus systems, to actual models of real systems, particularly those for the state of Washington and Texas. This TTP effort required developing and testing the core operations of an end-to-end EMS systems. Incorporating these core modules into IncSys? basic simulation platform allowed rigorous testing of the attacks and countermeasures thereby making it available for cybersecurity training of EMS operators across the USA.  The resulting cybersecurity exercises have led to a curriculum that is being refined for North American Electric Reliability Council (NERC) certification.

 

This project?s key findings are that if grid operators manage the grid with real-time situational monitoring including contingency analysis and security constrained generation response, then the system is much more resilient to all, including and especially intelligent and sophisticated, cyberattacks. This research led to published papers in a multitude of power systems focused conferences including the flagship conference, the IEEE Power and Energy Systems General Meetings (GM) from 2015--2019 (our paper on machine learning countermeasures was featured as a talk in the Best of Conference Paper session for 2017), IEEE SmartGridComm 2016-2019. Our detailed journal papers have been accepted to the prestigious IEEE Transactions on Power Systems as well as the IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid and the IET Smart Grid Transactions. Moreover, dissemination also included the following: invitation to present a lecture on our platform and our research on the cybersecurity panel at IEEE PES GM 2019 in Atlanta, GA, invitation to present at the MIT forum on data science in Engineering in 2017, and invitations to be the chair for the cybersecurity and privacy symposium of the IEEE SmartGridComm 2017 and 2018 conferences. The research is well cited and stands out in being one of the few that not only demonstrated in theory but also in practice the need for intelligent detection of cyberattacks. 

 

This project also involved an active outreach component to power industry members and researchers. This project was also additionally supported by PSERC, the power systems engineering research center, an NSF IU-CRC, that allowed showcasing the work to industry members concerned about security of grid operations. A significant outreach effort of this project is operator training and exposure to cybersecurity challenges in the grid, particularly for EMS operations, in collaboration with IncSys and PowerData. This included operator training sessions to several utility and operators across the USA, including to SRP in Arizona, PJM and MISO in the Northeast and Midwest USA, respectively. Finally, the developed software platform is available for those interested in testing attacks and evaluating the incorporated countermeasures. Details on the software platform, the visualization framework, and the key project outcomes can also be found at https://tinyurl.com/y4a5trjz.
